p:
Chemists have succeeded in designing and synthesizing a large variety of artificial molecular machines
16– 18 and in recent years, the asymmetry and chirality of dynamic and responsive molecules has been harnessed to drive complex macroscopic motion
19 , e.g., the twisting of springs
20 , the rotation of patterns
21 , and the emergence of pulsating vortices
22 . Even so, in all these examples motion sees the center of mass of the object fixed, or in other words the molecular motion fails to convert into motile behavior.
